Mystical Orient or Thriving Western City?

Hong Kong is a delightful study of merging cultures, economies and lifestyles.
Architecture, new and old, is Hong Kong's most notable contrast. More than 1,000 high-rise buildings tower over the city and surround Victoria Harbour. Majestic mountains are a calming backdrop to the skyscrapers, mixing nature with modern development. Spectacular lights illuminate the night sky as The Center's neon show marks the end of another day, while the Symphony of Lights music and laser show plays across 44 Hong Kong buildings to set the stage for another night of pulsing discos and nightclubs.

Hong Kong's historic buildings are low-tech but no less grand than the mighty skyscrapers. Testaments to the city's long-time religious freedoms, Hong Kong is full of ancient temples and churches. Ohel Leah Synagogue, Hung Shing Temple and Lin Fa Temple are tucked among the city's skyscrapers, but head away from the city's tallest buildings to see the stunning traditional Muslim architecture of Kowloon Masjid.

Victoria Peak offers gorgeous views of the city, harbors and Lamma Island. The trip to The Peak is an adventure in its own right aboard the funicular railway Peak Tram.

Industry, Entertainment and the Edo Period

A thriving metropolis lures thousands of business travelers to Osaka each year. In a city where the daytime population out-steps the nighttime population by more than one million people, Osaka is truly a working town. Its metropolitan area includes the cities of Kyoto and Kobe, making it the world's seventh largest metropolitan economy. 

Its notable electronics industry is secured with headquarters of many technology giants, including Sharp, Sanyo and Panasonic. The city's economic success is beautifully showcased by the Umeda Sky Building's twin towers connected by a rooftop bridge and Floating Garden. For business and pleasure travelers, the sky bridge is a great location to take in extraordinary views of the city and relish the wonder of Japan.

More technological wonders are on display in Osaka's Dotonbori Bridge district. Noted for its conglomeration of electronic signs to rival New York City's Times Square and its infamous giant mechanical crab, Osaka's entertainment district is lively and diverse. It's the perfect spot to end a day of traveling, working or sightseeing.

The country's premier rice-trading post during the Edo Period, Osaka earned the nickname, "The Nation's Kitchen." While rice-trading no longer dominates the city's economy, the city's reputation for world class cuisine continues the legend. The city's numerous casual and fine dining restaurants and countless street vendors are great spots to re-fuel for your Osaka travels.

Reveal the Soul of Seoul

Although it's known more for its status as a modern international city and technology center, a wealth of history, art and cuisine thrives in Seoul. Whether you are in town for business or pleasure, make time to visit the heart of Seoul, the Gyeongbokung Palace. Seoul was built around this 14th century Joseon royal seat and it bears the marks of the intervening centuries, including Korean War bullet holes. Four other impressive Joseon Dynasty palaces make up the legendary Five Grand Palaces and are not to be missed.

Ancient dynasties and rulers have given way to today's ruling class of Seoul, the booming technology and electronics industry. For business professionals traveling to Seoul, the opportunities here are colossal. Seoul is home to some of the world's largest and most successful electronics firms, participating in a national economy that is ranked No. 4 in the world. Be poised to make the most of your opportunities in Seoul by traveling in the restful comfort of luxury. Diplomats, Financiers and Hindu Deities

With its prospering financial markets, diplomatic missions and treasured landmarks, Kuala Lumpur is the sixth most popular world destination. For business travelers, the city is home to most foreign embassies, a burgeoning service sector and a growing hub of global Islamic financing. This showpiece of finance and economic progress is evident in the city's many high-rise buildings and its iconic, record-setting Petronas Twin Towers. For a quick break between business meetings, the twin towers offer a stunning view of the city, as does the 1,381-foot Kuala Lumpur Tower spire.

Home to the Malaysian king's official residence, Kuala Lumpur has a relatively short history that is best explored through its many buildings and open spaces. View the site where the country shed its British colonial flag in 1957 at Merdeka Square, or get a feel for the town's pioneers at its Chinatown on Petaling Street. First-rate shopping, endless museums and an energetic nightlife bring extra entertainment to your exotic Kuala Lumpur voyage.

Natural and religious wonders are located throughout the sprawling city. Delight in the Moorish architecture of Jamek Mosque, officially opened by the Sultan of Selangor in 1909. Explore the astonishing Batu Caves, guarded by an expansive shrine and a 140-foot tall gilded statue of the Hindu deity Murugan. Hindu drawings, statues and shrines are sprinkled throughout the site's three main caves and many smaller caves. While on site, enjoy one of the 160 rock climbing routes among the caves and the surrounding mountainside. 

In the Lap of Luxury Travel in Cheap Business Class Flight

Once you board your airplane, you'll enjoy five-star meals, spacious seats, bed turn-down service, ample work space and services catered to your needs.

The ABCs of Amsterdam: Art, Bicycles and Canals

The wealthiest city in the world during its 17th-century Dutch Golden Age, Amsterdam still benefits from the succinct city planning of that era. The Amstel River ends in the center of town and connects to four half-rings of canals that end at the IJ Bay. These canals make traveling through Amsterdam simple and convenient, reduce the number of cars on the road and give the city its quaint atmosphere. Bicycling is a way of life here, so consider renting a bicycle to tour around town when not traveling by boat.

Architecture and history buffs delight in Amsterdam's plentiful historic buildings. From its oldest, Oude Kerk, constructed in 1306 to its modern VanGogh Museum, travelers can spend days roaming the town investigating its charming buildings. 

Eight iconic windmills still inhabit Amsterdam. Touring all eight windmills, including the 1725-built De Gooyer Windmill, is a fantastic way to spend an afternoon.

A cultural melting pot, Amsterdam celebrates its many sides in more than 50 museums, including its most famous: the Rijksmuseum and the Stedelijk Museum. For more recent history, visit the house where Anne Frank, her family and the Van Pels hid from Nazi police.


True to its professed social tolerance, Amsterdam allows local coffee shops to sell small amounts of cannabis to those who are at least 18 years old. The city also allows legal prostitution, conducted in a controlled manner and in designated areas. The town's most visited red-light district is De Wallen.

Travel in Luxury in Business Class 

Long flights to Amsterdam can be pleasurable and affordable with FlyFirst's discount business class flights and stellar first class deals. Your extravagant experience begins at the airport with entree to select airport lounges featuring countless amenities and comforts. 

Once on your airplane, the pampering continues with cushy seats, delectable dishes designed by world-famous chefs, plentiful entertainment, ample work space and privacy screens. The result of flying first and business class is that you arrive in beautiful Amsterdam feeling rested and able to explore the city's many faces.

Volcanoes, Bungies and Pristine Beaches

Warm, sunny days and ancient traditions highlight the embracing energy surrounding New Zealand's largest city. Nestled between two vital harbors, one leading to the Tasman Sea and the other to the Pacific Ocean, Auckland is well-placed for industries relying on shipping and for tourists looking for plentiful water recreation. 

Auckland features dozens of thrills for travelers, including guided walking tours of the area's volcanoes led by descendants of the local Maori. Adventurers can walk where molten lava once flowed in the large lava tubes on Rangitoto Island, just a half-hour ferry ride from Auckland.

A thrill-seeker's paradise, New Zealand is the home of bungy-jumping, which remains a popular activity for travelers ready for a little excitement. Jump from the Auckland Bridge or plunge from the Sky Tower's 630-foot tall platform to get your adrenaline flowing, and experience stellar views of the city and harbors.

Once you've conquered the mountains, volcanoes and bungy cords, enjoy live Polynesian music, dance, local crafts and foods at the Saturday morning Otara Flea Markets. It's a great spot to mix with local Kiwis and see the real Auckland. For a relaxing afternoon, bicycle along Tamaki Drive's waterfront or dine at any of the celebrated Viaduct Harbour/Princes Wharf district restaurants.

The area's plentiful and stunning beaches offer rest and recreation just moments from downtown Auckland. For tranquil solitude, try Wattle Bay in Awhitu on Manutau Harbor, or for novelty, sink your toes in the black-sand beaches of Muriwai.

Tranquil Cities Call for Tranquil Journeys

Vibrant Cultures, Vital Industries, Vivid Colors

Although it's been decades since Thailand was known as Siam, the country's cherished historic cultures and landmarks remain, and there's no better place to experience those treasures than in the booming city of Bangkok. 

The third most popular tourist destination in the world, Bangkok is set on the Chao Phraya River delta. It's home to many awe-inspiring, colorful Buddhist temples, including Wat Arun on the river's west bank. Wat Arun's impressive 230-foot spire is one of Bangkok's most notable landmarks and is intricately brilliant architecture. Bangkok's largest temple, Wat Pho, features a vivid red and yellow exterior and an extraordinary 154-foot, gold-plated reclining Buddha. Whether you are traveling for business or for pleasure, the temples' amazingly detailed designs and sacred nature are not to be missed.

With all of its meaningful historical sites, it's easy to forget that Bangkok is a thriving metropolis. Home to dozens of regional headquarters for multinational companies, Bangkok is a Southeast Asian center of industry and finance. 

As a modern city, Bangkok brims with all the amenities and adventures you would expect of a major international hot spot. Abundant shopping centers surround the city's Siam Square, as do most of Bangkok's many high-rises and skyscrapers. Although infamous for its red-light district, Bangkok has a dynamic, legal nightlife scene. After a busy day of sightseeing or meetings, unwind a little and take in the exciting nightclubs in the Patpong district and along Khaosan Road.

Come for the Thrills

Brisbane River winds its way through much of the beautiful, walkable city. Skyscrapers in Brisbane's central business district ascend from the river bank, creating an unforgettable skyline and a brilliant sight for nighttime river cruisers. It's a bustling downtown, too, supporting the largest economy between Singapore and Sydney and a robust natural resources boom. The city brims with distributions hubs for global electronics companies, making Brisbane a frequent destination for international business travelers.

In addition to its stellar river access, Brisbane lies between Moreton Bay and the Great Dividing Range, forming the perfect trifecta for adventurers. Animal lovers adore the Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary, where snuggling with a koala is encouraged, and visitors can feed kangaroos and wallabies. For bigger thrills, climb the 260-foot Story Bridge and rappel down, kayak or sail along Moreton Bay, take a Tree Top Walk along nine suspension bridges, cycle along the Riverwalk or climb the towering rocks of Kangaroo Point.

Those looking to expand their cultural horizons delight in the grand architecture of ANZAC Shrine, the Customs House, Albert Street Uniting Church and Parliament House. The town's notable live music scene includes opera, symphony orchestra and many performing choirs.

From adventure and outdoor activities to local theater performances and plentiful shopping, there's something for everyone in Brisbane. Even if you are stuck in meetings during the day, there are plenty of nighttime cruises and performances that allow you to enjoy Brisbane's many thrills.

Churches, Theaters and Sports Arenas

At the center of Munich is the Marientplatz, the heart of old Munich. Here, visitors delight in the historic buildings and grand architecture of New Town Hall and the old medieval city's gates: Isartor, Karlstor and Sendlinger Tor. The Marientplatz is home to Frauenkirche, ornately beautiful and the inner city's most famous church.

In fact, Munich houses dozens of stunning, historic churches. Near the Marientplatz, tourists can find the largest Renaissance church north of the Alps at St. Michael's Church, the domed Theatine Church of St. Cajetan and St. Anna of Lehel, Bavaria's first rococo church.

Travelers and locals alike revel in the city's renowned museums and theaters adjacent to Old Town at the Residenz palace complex. Relish a breathtaking performance at the National Theater, the site where several of Richard Wagner's operas premiered, or enjoy a show at the Residenz Theater. Stroll along some of Munich's famed royal avenues to see a variety of Bavaria's other fascinating structures such as The Maximilianeum and Nymphenburg Palace.

Sports and community events are popular in Munich. Take in a game at the ultra-modern Allianz Arena, home to two professional soccer teams: Bayern Munich and 1860 Munich. It's a special treat at night as the spherical-shaped arena changes colors. For a little taste of the local brew, head to the Hofbräuhaus am Platzl, one of the world's most famous beer halls and the site of an immense Oktoberfest celebration.

Rivers, Churches and Koalas

Smaller, but no less thrilling and picturesque than Sydney and Melbourne, Adelaide is a vibrant and contemporary city teeming with defense and manufacturing industries. The city reaches from southern Australia's Gulf of St. Vincent to Mount Lofty Ranges, offering abundant recreation, brilliant scenery and foothills that are perfect for thriving vineyards.

The River Torrens flows through sparkling Adelaide, creating plentiful riverside promenades, parks and trails enticing locals and visitors to bicycle, stroll and jog along the river's banks. Many of Adelaide's most beautiful structures are set along the river, as are many of the town's famed festivals.

Nicknamed the "City of Churches" for its abundant places of worship, Adelaide's most well-known church is the stunning Gothic Revival St. Francis Xavier's Cathedral. Other don't-miss places to tour include Parliament House, Chinatown, Adelaide Botanic Garden and South Australian Museum, where you'll find the world's largest collection of Australian Aboriginal artifacts.

Head to the Adelaide Hills for breathtaking views and scrumptious wines. Just east of the city in the Mount Lofty Ranges, is one of Australia's largest wine regions. It is home to more than 90 wineries producing world-class red and white wines. More than half of the wineries offer tours, tastings and master classes, providing days of entertainment and palate-pleasing adventures for wine lovers.

For even more thrilling experiences, head west to Kangaroo Island, where koalas doze in Eucalyptus trees at Paul's Place Wildlife Sanctuary and pelicans soar above the beaches. Sailing, hiking, fishing and touring the island's many conservation areas offer both exhilarating and tranquil adventures.

Luxuriate in the Journey

Give yourself the pampering experience you deserve by flying to Adelaide in the peaceful luxury of first or business class. From the minute you enter the airport, you'll be treated to comforts beyond belief. On your flight, you'll delight in spacious seats, personal entertainment systems and five-star quality meals.

Delicious, Divine and Deluxe

Dubai's economic vigor is evident in its manicured streets and abundant skyscrapers. Home to the only seven-star hotel on earth, Dubai offers plenty of high-end entertainment, lodging and recreation in a pristine, yet lush tropical setting.
 
Given the city's tendency for immense proportions, it's not surprising that Dubai's shopping malls are some of the largest in the world. An experience in its own right, the Dubai Mall holds more than 1,000 shops, more than 160 eateries, a 22-screen cinema, an ice rink and an aquarium. 
 
Once you've had your fill of modern sites, explore the Arabian Peninsula's history at the old Burj Nahar watchtower, the Hatta Heritage Village and the Dubai Museum. Jumeirah Mosque is one of the area's largest mosques, featuring exquisite medieval Fatimid-styled minarets and pristine white dome. The old souks, are ideal marketplaces to experience the traditions and culture of Dubai. Fine fabrics, gold and local wares are great finds at the local souks.
 
Several theme parks offer thrills galore for Dubai visitors, while the area's nature reserves provide exciting views of waterbirds such as broad-billed sandpipers and flamingos.

Palaces, Tapas and Culture

The capital of Spain, bustling Madrid is the third largest European Union city and the cultural and political center of the country. The city is headquarters for most Spain-based corporations and home to a vibrant European financial center.

Visitors revel in the city's rich heritage and history at sites like the Almundena Cathedral, built in 1883 on the grounds of a medieval mosque. The cathedral is a majestic symbol of the city's Catholic roots, with its gilded statue of Madonna and Child and exquisite Gothic Revival architecture. The immense and impressive Royal Palace of Madrid is a stunning 3,418 rooms, many of them on display during tours. There are countless other architectural wonders in Madrid, including the Plaza de Cibeles, featuring the Palacio de Buenavista, Palacio de Cibeles, the Bank of Spain, the Palacio de Linares and a variety of enticing fountains and appealing statues.

Culture abounds here, with the historic Royal Theater, the Golden Triangle of Art, the Royal Botanical Garden and dozens of other fascinating museums. Visitors seeking a thrilling nightlife don't have to look far in Madrid. Tapas bars, jazz lounges and flamenco theaters are scattered throughout and offer the perfect culmination to a day spent roaming the magnificent. Some of the city's favorite nightspots are located in the Puerto de Sol, Tribunal and Bilbao districts.

Skyscrapers, History and Safaris

This modern city is home to a number of international corporations and financial empires, evident in its many towering buildings. Sentech Tower, Carlton Centre and Hillbrow Tower are just a few of the city's imposing buildings offering stunning views of the metropolis.

In spite of its gleaming modern style, Johannesburg offers much more than just towering skyscrapers. Visitors revel in wandering through the Johannesburg Botanical Garden or spending a day enjoying thrill rides, underground mine tours and tribal dancing performances at Gold Reef City.

The city's rich and complicated history is wonderfully explored at the Apartheid Museum, Harry Pieterson Museum, Constitution Hill and the Mandela Museum. The region's role in the development of man is displayed just outside of town at The Cradle of Humankind. The site of the Sterkfontein fossil and the richest hominid discoveries in the world, the Cradle of Humankind is a World Heritage Site. 

Johannesburg teems with more modern cultural exploits, as well, including lively shopping and art scenes. Visitors delight in the high-end shops at Sandton City and Nelson Mandela Square and the local crafts at the Rosebank Flea Market. Several art museums and performing arts venues call Johannesburg home, including Johannesburg Art Museum and Market Theater.

Located in Africa's highveld, Johannesburg teems with captivating wildlife. More than 80 lions, including rare white lions, can be seen at the Lion Park near Lanseria Airport. Visitors also enjoy the safari adventures at Krugersdorp Nature Reserve, about 45 minutes from Johannesburg.

Waterfront Wonders, Brilliant Seascapes and Dramatic Cliffs

Known for its dramatic sea cliffs, majestic Table Mountain and a vibrant harbor, bi-coastal Cape Town has plenty of magnificent sights and activities. Befitting the most popular tourist destination in Africa, Cape Town overflows with attractions, including the Victoria & Albert Waterfront. The waterfront showcases hundreds of shops, the Two Oceans Aquarium and the Nelson Mandela Gateway. Visitors delight in riding the ferries out to Simon's Town, Robben Island and Hout Bay and touring Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden.

Beaches of every variety surround Cape Town, from the wide, sandy beaches of the eastern False Bay to the popular surfing beaches along the West Coast. With spectacular sunset views on the Atlantic Coast beaches, Cape Town offers views that rival all others. Visitors especially relish the views to be found along the cliffside Chapman's Peak Drive between Hout Bay and Noordhoek.

Fascinating Table Mountain, with its richly diverse vegetation, offers plenty of recreation and excitement. Visitors can reach the peak by hiking up the mountain or riding the Table Mountain Cableway. From the upper cableway, tourists enjoy amazing views of the city, the mountain and Robben Island.

Adventure and wonder await in the magnificent city of Cairo. Journey to the City of a Thousand Minarets in affordable luxury with FlyFirst.com's stellar first class deals and business class fares. You'll save as much as 70 percent off published fares and enjoy untold luxuries on your way to the desert gem of Cairo.

Pharaohs, Bazaars and Minarets

From age-old civilizations to gleaming modern skyscrapers, Cairo is at once both ancient and modern. Set along the life-giving Nile River, Cairo is near many of the compelling ancient pyramids of Giza, the city of Memphis, the iconic Sphinx and the Saqqara Pyramid Complex featuring Imhotep's step pyramid. Travelers can experience the lifestyle, ingenuity and craftsmanship of ancient peoples at the nearby living history site, Pharaonic Village.

Stunning architecture and religious history are displayed in the city's many notable mosques. At the center of town, perched on Muqattam Hill in Cairo's historic Citadel fortress, the Mosque of Muhammad Ali overlooks the ancient city. Many of the city's mosques are gorgeous examples of 10th and 11th century Islamic architecture, including Al-Hakim Mosque Jame-al-Anwar, Al Azhar and Lulua mosques. All built between 928 and 1015, these mosques showcase marble courtyards, towering minarets and keel-shaped arches.

The city richly offers more modern sites as well, from its "Paris on the Nile" architecture in downtown to its celebrated Tahrir (Liberation) Square. Famed Museum of Egyptian Antiquities encourages visitors to marvel at countless ancient artifacts and mummies, including those found with King Tutankhamun and the most recently discover Hatshepsut.

For a true taste of the city's lifestyle, board a local felucca (boat) for a sunset cruise of the Nile or shop in the diverse and vibrant ancient bazaar, Khan el-Khalili. Wander through the narrow, winding streets of Old Cairo to browse through the Coptic Museum and Babylon Fortress or admire the architecture and reverence of Egypt's first mosque, Amr ibn al-'As Mosque. Sip coffee at a sidewalk cafe, puff on a sheesha water pipe or savor the Middle Eastern flavors of kushari rice dishes and fatir pastries at street vendors and local restaurants. 

Relish the Trip of a Lifetime in Discounted Business Class 

Begin your journey to Cairo with the splendor and luxury of first class seats or business class tickets, courtesy of FlyFirst's deeply discounted fares. Vaporetti, Venetian Masks and Virtuosos

Situated on the northeastern coast of Italy in the Venetian Lagoon, Venice is filled with canals winding through its ancient streets. Its Gothic buildings, romantic bridges and absence of cars create a city that seems untouched by modern times. It is Venice's charming ambiance, overflowing with history and artistry, that draws more than 50,000 tourists a day. Venice is so steeped in history, in fact, that the entire city is a World Heritage Site.

A journey to Venice is an unforgettable adventure. Relish a sunset ride in the city's vaporetti water buses or gondolas, see Casanova's jail at the Doge's Palace or watch a master glass blower create a stunning art piece. Tour Piazza San Marco's basilica and Campanile, the gilded La Fenice opera house and the famed Rialto Bridge to experience the city's acclaimed history. Savor spectacular views of the Grand Canal while browsing through the Rialto market or boat to the picturesque island of San Giorgio Maggiore. Enjoy elaborate costumes, local mask artistry and a surreal sense of theater during the city's famed Carnival, or relax with the glitterati on the luxurious beaches of nearby Lido di Venezia.

Aside from its fine Venetian and Murano glass blowers and magnificent mask makers, Venice has been home to countless artists, leaders and power-brokers throughout its 1,500-year history. As you roam Venice's enchanting streets, you walk in the footsteps of some of Western civilization's most important figures, from Marco Polo and Sebastian Cabot to Titian and Antonio Vivaldi.

Create an Unforgettable Journey to Venice

With Venice's bountiful experiences, you'll want to arrive rested and ready to explore. Sumptuous first class flights and business class seats envelop you in the lap of luxury and deliver you to one of Europe's most romantic cities. Gold, Gardens, Gables and Grapes

Melbourne is a study of contrasts. Here, enchanting Victorian buildings are shadowed by towering modern skyscrapers and high-rises and well-planned grid-like streets hide small, winding "laneways" filled with funky boutiques. Although the city honors its role in the 1850s Gold Rush, it is a cosmopolitan wonder as the country's biotechnology and automotive center. 
Known as Australian's garden city, Melbourne overflows with parks, formal gardens and landscaped spaces. Visitors relish the green space, fountains, statues and trees filling Fitzroy Garden and the tropical glasshouse, aboriginal heritage walks and the Melbourne Observatory at the Royal Botanic Garden. 
Tourists delight in the city's numerous Victorian buildings. From Parliament House and the State Library to Melbourne Town Hall and St. Patrick's Cathedral, the buildings are fascinating glimpses into Australian life in the mid-19th century. The Royal Exhibition Building is a local favorite, constructed for the world's fare in 1880 and a now a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Modern buildings offer even more engaging experiences, from the vibrant, immense Australian rules football stadiums to the deconstructionist buildings in bustling Federation Square. While at the Square, take in a film at the uniquely constructed Australian Centre for the Moving Image or marvel at the Square's unusual shard walls.
Shopping is popular in Melbourne. One-of-a-kind boutiques, charming cafes, appealing restaurants and glimmering galleries line the city's treasured "laneways" hidden behind the city's regular streets and offer hours of shopping and dining pleasure.
Enticing beaches surround the eastern coastline near Melbourne, particularly the picturesque St. Kilda, just about three miles from the city. Surfers can find bomboras (big waves) about 50 miles southeast of Melbourne at Rye, Portsea and Sorrento.
After taking in the city's countless charms, many tourists revel in a day trip to the east, where the Yarra Valley offers gorgeous vineyards and dozens of wineries offering tastings and tours.

Sophisticated Destinations Deserve Sophisticated Journeys

Travel in the sumptuous luxury of reduced business class seats, first class tickets and last minute flights with FlyFirst.com. Milan: A Cultural Mecca For the Centuries

Italy's finance, commerce, fashion and interior design industries are centered in Milan. Home to the Italian stock exchange, most of the country's major banks and the world's leading fashion designers, the city's newest gems are the gleaming skyscrapers and cultural centers in the dazzling Porta Nuova Business District. Whether you travel to Milan for business or pleasure, this revitalized district offers plenty of attraction.
 
In addition to a vibrant business sector, Milan is a mecca for travelers interested in history, architecture and art. More than two million visitors each year explore the city's treasures, from Leonardo da Vinci's The Last Supper at Santa Maria delle Grazie to Botticelli's Madonna of the Pavilion. Grand buildings in Piazzo del Duomo span the centuries. There, the Duomo's 135 Gothic spires rise above the city and face the breathtaking facades of the Royal Palace, Arengario Palace, and Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, the world's oldest shopping mall. Impressive Sforza Castle museums, the historic Arch of Peace and the famed La Scala opera house all offer their own particular delights.
 
A fashion paradise, Milan is the headquarters for a number of celebrated design houses, including Armani, Dolce & Gabbana, Versace, Valentino, Prada and Gucci. High-end fashion houses and boutiques can be found along such streets as Via della Spiga, Via Manzoni and Via Monte Napoleone.

Towers, Temples and More

Historic and modern, Taipei offers plenty of attractions for visitors of every age. Modern Taipei brims with skyscrapers, industry and fast-paced entertainment. The second tallest building in the world, Taipei 101, offers dazzling views of the city on its 89th floor and 91st floor observation decks. From there, head to the surrounding Xinyi District for abundant shopping and entertainment. Stores, nightclubs, restaurants and performances fill the district and make it popular day and night.

Find more traditional nightlife at any of Taipei's many iconic night markets. Perennial favorite Shilin Night Market overflows with food stalls, regional wares and plenty of local flavor. In the daytime, explore the area's culture at the dozens of notable museums, such as the National Palace Museum. There, you'll view one of the world's largest displays of ancient Chinese artifacts, including jades, ceramics and paintings.

Walk in the footsteps of world leaders at the Grand Hotel, one of the largest classical Chinese buildings in the world. The hotel hosted U.S. presidents, British prime ministers, Middle Eastern kings and other world leaders. Philippine leader Benigno Aquino stayed at the Grand Hotel the night before his assassination.

History and the arts combine at Liberty Square, with the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, the National Theater and the National Concert Hall. Liberty Square was the site of several pro-democratic rallies in the 1980s and early 1990s credited for hastening democratic rule in the country.

Relish the varied religious history of the area at various temples in the region, ranging from Buddhist and Chinese folk to Taoist faiths. Travel the "Road to Heaven," Xinsheng South Road, to view some of Taipei's notable temples and churches, or visit the ornately decorated Mengjia Longshan Temple.

Old Town Charm With A Modern Twist

Set on the Rhine River, Düsseldorf's Alstadt district looks as if it was conjured straight from a fairytale book. Quaint cobblestone streets wind through old buildings adorned with colorful flower boxes and trailing ivy. Old-fashioned wrought iron street lamps illuminate the lanes and sidewalk cafes. Here, visitors soak in the Old World ambiance of medieval St. Lambertus Church; the Renaissance town hall, Rathaus; and the old castle tower's shipping museum. Düsseldorf's famed crisp Altbier is served at four of Alstadt's pubs, brewed on-site in the traditional way. A welcoming river promenade trails alongside the Rhine, perfect for strolling, jogging and skating. Just across from the peaceful promenade, the modern world flavors Düsseldorf's "longest bar in the world," a series of more than 300 lively discos and bars.

Alstadt isn't the only historic district in town. The Kaiserswerth area holds the ruins of Castle Barbarossa and Florence Nightingale's old work site, the Deaconess' Institute of Kaiserswerth. Visitors delight in the rococo ornamentation of 18th century Schloss Benrath, the grand dome of the Tonhalle Concert Hall and the city's plentiful museums and theaters. 

For more modern experiences, visitors head to the Rhine Tower, Rheinturm, where a revolving restaurant and observation deck offer spectacular views. A lighted clock sculpture rests atop the tower, creating the world's largest digital clock. Shoppers enjoy the countless high-end jewelry and designer apparel shops in the Königsallee/King's Avenue area. Botanical gardens, bountiful parks, a bustling harbor and the ever-present Rhine River provide ample opportunities for visitors and locals to enjoy the cool climate and verdant landscape that is quintessentially Düsseldorf.

A Delight For the Senses

Known for its environmentally conscious practices, Copenhagen is one of the most bicycle-friendly cities in the world. For a true sense of the city, hop on a bike and join the hundreds of other locals cruising past Cophenhagen's colorful buildings, canals and parks. Whether you are in town for business or pleasure, a cycle through town is an unforgettable experience

Copenhagen offers bountiful business opportunities, particularly in the biotechnology and life sciences industries. The city is home to more than 300 "cleantech" companies and is headquarters for two of the world's top 50 biotechnology firms. Shipping, service-oriented companies and countless multinational corporations base regional and international operations in Copenhagen, making it a top destination for professionals.

The beautiful city offers many historical attractions, including the Marble Church, the iconic Little Mermaid statue and Christiansborg Palace. Marvel at the rococo details of Amalienborg Palace. Relish the vibrantly colored Danish homes of 17th century Nyhavn, the city's waterfront and entertainment district. Tour some of the churches and spires that give the city its nickname, particularly the famed corkscrew spire at the Church of Our Savior. Wander through the city's oldest park at King's Garden and Rosenborg Castle, or mingle with other visitors and locals in Amagertorv square.

Even Copenhagen's amusement parks are historic. The oldest working amusement park in the world, Dyrehavsbakken pleasure park was created in 1583 and is now home to many rides, restaurants and games. Popular Tivoli Gardens is the second oldest amusement park in the world and offers plenty of thrill rides for the entire family.

After a day of meetings or city tours, check out Copenhagen's oft-lauded New Nordic cuisine, rousing nightclubs, abundant microbreweries or its treasured pastry shops.
